transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Alright everyone, sit down. Let's get this over with. We have a lot to cover today and I don't want to stay late. My name is the Fellow for today. You know why you're here. We are talking about mindset, specifically how you are born with a certain amount of brains and you just have to deal with it.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: Wait, I thought this was supposed to be about how we can improve? I've been struggling with math and I was hoping for some tips.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Don't interrupt me, Jabari. I'll get to that. If you're bad at math, you're probably just not a math person. Some people have the 'math gene' and some don't. It's just science. Anyway, let's do an icebreaker. Tell me your name and your favorite color. Start with Amani.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Um, okay. I'm Amani. I like blue. But I actually wanted to agree with Jabari, I read that the brain is like a muscle?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: No, that's a common misconception. Your brain is more like a fixed hard drive. Once it's full or the specs are set, that's it. Keziah, your turn. Color.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I'm Keziah. I like green. I feel a bit discouraged hearing that, though. I've been working really hard on my poetry and I thought I was getting better because of the effort.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: You might be getting 'better' at the craft, but your innate talent level is static. Leo, go ahead.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I'm Leo. Red. Honestly, if what you're saying is true, why am I even in this group? If I can't change how I handle stress or my grades, this is a waste of time.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: It's not a waste of time because I'm the one teaching it. You need to listen to the definitions. Now, Sara.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I'm Sara. Yellow. I don't know, my teacher told me that a 'Growth Mindset' means we can grow our intelligence. You're saying the opposite.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Your teacher is trying to be nice to you so you don't give up. I'm being realistic. Sam, finish us off.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I'm Sam. Orange. I'm just here because I have to be. If I'm stuck being average, then I'll just stay average.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, Sam. Acceptance is key. Now, let's move on to the main concept: Fixed Intelligence. This is the idea that your IQ is set at birth. You can't really change it. If you fail a test, it's because you're not smart enough for that subject. It's better to know your limits than to try and fail.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: That sounds really depressing. Amani, don't you think that sounds wrong? I saw a video about neuroplasticity.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: I do! Jabari, I think the Fellow is missing the point of the Shamiri model. Isn't this supposed to be about growth?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Amani, stop talking. I am the facilitator here. Neuroplasticity is for babies. By the time you're teenagers, your paths are mostly set. Let's look at real-life examples. If you try to play basketball and you're short, you'll never be LeBron James. That's a fixed reality.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: But you can still get better at basketball! You don't have to be LeBron to be good.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Leo, don't argue with me. It's about efficiency. Why spend hours practicing something you aren't naturally gifted at? It's a waste of energy. Let's do an activity. Write down three things you are bad at and accept that you will always be bad at them.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I don't want to do that. That feels like I'm giving up on myself. Sara, are you going to write that?

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: No way. I'm writing down things I want to get better at. This feels like the opposite of therapy.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: It's not therapy, it's a session, and you're not following instructions. If you don't write down your weaknesses, you're living in a fantasy. Jabari, what did you write?

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I wrote 'Math,' but I also wrote '...yet' next to it. I'm bad at math *yet*.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: The 'yet' is a lie. Just cross it out. Sam, what about you?

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I wrote 'Socializing.' I'm bad at talking to people. And based on how this is going, I'm not getting any better today.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: See? Sam gets it. He's realistic. Now, for the reflection part. How does it feel to know you don't have to try so hard anymore?

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: It feels terrible! It feels like you're telling us we are stuck in our problems. I thought Shamiri was about 'shamiri,' which means to thrive!

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Thriving is about knowing your place. If you're a flower that needs shade, don't try to live in the sun. It's simple biology. We're almost out of time. For take-home work, I want you to go home and tell your parents one thing you've given up on.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I'm not doing that. I'm going to go home and study twice as hard just to prove you wrong.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That's just spite, Leo, not growth. Alright, we're done. Pack up. I have another group that hopefully listens better than you all do. Goodbye.
